back: The condition where limited resources cannot satisfy unlimited wants, forcing individuals and societies to make choices about resource allocation
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students think scarcity means 'shortage'; scarcity exists even in rich economies and is permanent, whereas a shortage is a temporary market condition

back: The value of the next best alternative that is given up when a choice is made
CLEP Trap: Trap: Often confused with 'all alternatives given up'; only the single highest-valued foregone option counts as opportunity cost

back: A curve showing the maximum combinations of two goods an economy can produce with fixed resources and technology
CLEP Trap: Trap: Points inside the PPC are not impossible, they are inefficient; points outside are unattainable with current resources

front: Points on, inside, and outside PPC
back: On the curve: efficient; inside: inefficient/unemployment; outside: unattainable with current resources
CLEP Trap: Trap: Questions may describe unemployment and ask which PPC location it implies; many mistakenly pick a point on the curve instead of inside

back: Shown as an outward shift of the PPC, indicating increased productive capacity due to more resources or better technology
CLEP Trap: Trap: Moving along an existing PPC is not growth, it is a reallocation of resources

back: The ability of a producer or country to produce more of a good with the same resources than another producer or country
CLEP Trap: Trap: Test items ask about who should specialize; specialization is based on comparative advantage, not absolute advantage

back: The ability to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another producer or country
CLEP Trap: Trap: Many students incorrectly choose the country that can produce the most (absolute advantage) instead of the lowest opportunity cost

back: The agreed rate at which two goods are exchanged between countries; beneficial if it lies between each country's opportunity cost for that good
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students forget the 'between opportunity costs' rule and accept trade terms that favor only one country

back: As the price of a good falls, the quantity demanded rises, ceteris paribus, and vice versa
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing a change in demand (shift) with a change in quantity demanded (movement along the curve)

back: As the price of a good rises, the quantity supplied rises, ceteris paribus, and vice versa
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students sometimes think 'supply increases' when price rises, but that is a movement along the supply curve, not a shift

back: Non-price factors that shift demand: income, tastes, prices of related goods, expectations, and number of buyers
CLEP Trap: Trap: Price of the good itself does not shift the demand curve; only causes movement along the curve

back: Non-price factors that shift supply: input prices, technology, taxes and subsidies, expectations, and number of sellers
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students may treat a change in price of the good as a supply shifter instead of a movement along supply

back: The price and quantity at which quantity demanded equals quantity supplied, with no tendency to change
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing equilibrium with the 'fair' or 'desired' price; it is simply where Qd equals Qs

back: A legal maximum price set below equilibrium that creates a shortage when binding
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students mix up which control creates a shortage vs surplus; ceilings (if binding) create shortages

back: A legal minimum price set above equilibrium that creates a surplus when binding
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students reverse the effects and say 'price floor causes shortage'; actually it causes surplus if binding

back: Shortage: Qd > Qs at a price below equilibrium; Surplus: Qs > Qd at a price above equilibrium
CLEP Trap: Trap: Many mislabel shortages as surpluses and vice versa on graphs

back: Nominal values are measured in current prices; real values are adjusted for changes in the price level
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students interpret rising nominal GDP as higher real output without considering inflation

back: GDP = C + I + G + (X − M), where C is consumption, I is investment, G is government purchases, X is exports, and M is imports
CLEP Trap: Trap: Counting intermediate goods or transfer payments as part of GDP when they should be excluded

back: GDP measured using constant base-year prices to remove the effect of inflation and reflect actual output changes
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing real GDP with nominal GDP or with GDP per capita

back: A price index that measures the overall price level: GDP deflator = (nominal GDP / real GDP) * 100
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students mix up CPI and GDP deflator or use CPI formula for deflator questions

back: Price index = (cost of market basket in current year / cost of market basket in base year) * 100
CLEP Trap: Trap: In inflation problems, students sometimes reverse the numerator and denominator, flipping the index

back: Inflation rate = (price index in current year − price index in previous year) / (price index in previous year) * 100
CLEP Trap: Trap: Forgetting to divide by the previous year's index or treating the raw difference as the percent change

back: The sum of employed and unemployed people who are actively seeking work
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students mistakenly include discouraged workers who have stopped looking for work in the labor force

back: Unemployment rate = (number of unemployed / labor force) * 100
CLEP Trap: Trap: Using total population instead of labor force in the denominator

back: Frictional: between jobs; structural: skills mismatch; cyclical: due to downturns in the business cycle
CLEP Trap: Trap: Mislabeling all unemployment in recessions as structural when it is cyclical

back: The unemployment rate when the economy is at full employment, including only frictional and structural unemployment
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students think natural unemployment rate is zero; it never eliminates frictional and structural unemployment

back: The recurring pattern of expansion, peak, recession, and trough in real GDP over time
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing short-term fluctuations (cycles) with long-run growth trend

back: Total demand for goods and services in an economy at different price levels: AD = C + I + G + (X − M)
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students confuse aggregate demand with micro-level market demand for a single good

back: Wealth effect, interest rate effect, and net export effect cause AD to slope downward
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students try to explain AD slope with substitution effect, which is a micro concept

back: The relationship between price level and quantity of output supplied when some input prices are sticky
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing SRAS with LRAS and treating both as vertical

back: Vertical at potential output, representing full-employment real GDP when prices and wages are fully flexible
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students think an increase in price level shifts LRAS, but LRAS shifts only with real factors like technology and resources

back: When actual real GDP is below potential output; unemployment is above the natural rate
CLEP Trap: Trap: Some assume any inflation means no recessionary gap; recessionary gap focuses on output relative to potential, not just inflation

back: When actual real GDP is above potential output; unemployment is below the natural rate
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students mistake any high price level for an inflationary gap; what matters is output relative to potential

back: MPC (marginal propensity to consume) = change in consumption / change in income; MPS (marginal propensity to save) = change in saving / change in income; MPC + MPS = 1
CLEP Trap: Trap: Forgetting that MPC + MPS must equal 1 and using inconsistent values in multiplier questions

back: Multiplier = 1 / (1 − MPC) which equals 1 / MPS
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students invert the formula incorrectly or plug in total consumption instead of MPC

back: Tax multiplier = −MPC / (1 − MPC)
CLEP Trap: Trap: Forgetting that the tax multiplier is negative and smaller in magnitude than the spending multiplier

back: When increased government borrowing raises interest rates and reduces private investment, partially offsetting expansionary fiscal policy
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing crowding out with 'crowding in' or assuming government spending always fully boosts AD

back: Use of government spending and taxation to influence aggregate demand and stabilize the economy
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students confuse fiscal policy (G and T) with monetary policy (money supply and interest rates)

back: Policy that increases government spending and/or cuts taxes to increase AD and close a recessionary gap
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking tax cuts always increase AD even when they are not spent (MPC matters)

back: Policy that decreases government spending and/or raises taxes to reduce AD and fight inflation
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students mix up which direction government spending and taxes move under contractionary policy

back: Budget features like progressive taxes and unemployment benefits that automatically increase spending or cut taxes in recessions without new legislation
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing automatic stabilizers with discretionary fiscal actions that require a vote

back: The central bank's control of the money supply and interest rates to influence aggregate demand
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students name changes in government spending or taxation as monetary tools

back: Central bank buying or selling of government bonds to change the money supply
CLEP Trap: Trap: Reversing effects: buying bonds increases the money supply; selling bonds decreases it

back: Central bank bond purchases increase bank reserves, increase the money supply, and lower interest rates
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students often think bond purchases are contractionary because the central bank is 'spending money'

back: Central bank bond sales reduce bank reserves, decrease the money supply, and raise interest rates
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing selling bonds with expansionary policy; selling bonds is contractionary

back: The fraction of deposits banks must hold as reserves and not loan out
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating reserve ratio changes as trivial; on the exam, rr changes have big effects on money creation

back: Money multiplier = 1 / required reserve ratio
CLEP Trap: Trap: Using excess reserves instead of rr in the denominator or forgetting to convert rr from percent to decimal

back: Market where the supply and demand for money determine the nominal interest rate
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing the money market with the loanable funds market, which uses the real interest rate and different curves

back: Market for saving and borrowing where the real interest rate balances supply of and demand for loanable funds
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students use nominal interest rates when the diagram is clearly labeled with real interest

back: Real interest rate ≈ nominal interest rate − inflation rate
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students add instead of subtract or forget to adjust for inflation at all

back: Medium of exchange, unit of account, and store of value
CLEP Trap: Trap: Listing 'source of value' or 'measure of wealth' instead of the standard three functions

back: Includes currency in circulation and checkable (demand) deposits; the most liquid forms of money
CLEP Trap: Trap: Including savings accounts and large time deposits in M1 instead of M2

back: Shows an inverse relationship between inflation and unemployment in the short run
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking this relationship holds exactly in the long run; it only describes the short-run trade-off

back: Vertical at the natural rate of unemployment, showing no trade-off between inflation and unemployment in the long run
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students draw a downward-sloping long-run Phillips curve or assume policy can permanently lower unemployment with inflation

back: Inflation caused by increases in aggregate demand, often from expansionary policy or strong spending
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing demand-pull inflation with cost-push inflation from supply shocks

back: Inflation caused by decreases in short-run aggregate supply, often due to rising input costs or negative supply shocks
CLEP Trap: Trap: Mislabeling cost-push inflation as a demand shift when the correct curve is SRAS

back: Combination of high inflation and high unemployment, usually due to a negative supply shock shifting SRAS left
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming high inflation always goes with low unemployment because of the Phillips curve

back: Record of all transactions between residents of a country and the rest of the world, consisting of the current account and the financial account
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students think the balance of payments must always equal zero separately for each account, rather than overall

back: Part of the balance of payments that records trade in goods and services, net income from abroad, and net current transfers
CLEP Trap: Trap: Including purchases of foreign assets in the current account instead of the financial account

back: Part of the balance of payments that records purchases and sales of financial assets and real assets across borders
CLEP Trap: Trap: Mixing up financial account with current account, especially for bond and stock purchases

back: An increase in the value of a currency relative to another, meaning each unit buys more foreign currency
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students often think appreciation helps exports; it actually tends to reduce exports and increase imports

back: A decrease in the value of a currency, meaning each unit buys less foreign currency
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing depreciation with deflation; depreciation is about currency value, not domestic price level

front: Effect of appreciation on net exports
back: Appreciation makes exports more expensive and imports cheaper, tending to reduce net exports
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students say 'strong currency is always good' and forget it can hurt net exports

front: Effect of depreciation on net exports
back: Depreciation makes exports cheaper and imports more expensive, tending to increase net exports
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking depreciation hurts exports because currency is 'weak'; in fact, it helps export competitiveness

back: If domestic real interest rates rise relative to foreign rates, capital flows in, the domestic currency appreciates, and net exports fall
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students think higher interest rates always increase net exports because saving rises

back: Automatic stabilizers operate without new laws; discretionary policy requires deliberate legislative action
CLEP Trap: Trap: Labeling a voted stimulus package as 'automatic' when it is discretionary

front: Short run vs long run in macro
back: Short run: some prices and wages are sticky; long run: all prices and wages are flexible
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students apply long-run reasoning (vertical LRAS) to short-run AD-AS questions and vice versa

front: Economic growth vs business cycle expansion
back: Growth is a long-run upward trend in potential output; expansion is a short-run movement above recent output levels
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating any increase in GDP as long-run growth rather than distinguishing trend from cycle

back: The skills, knowledge, and health of workers that increase their productivity
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing human capital (intangible) with physical capital like machines and buildings

back: Produced resources such as machinery, tools, and buildings used to make other goods and services
CLEP Trap: Trap: Calling natural resources or money 'physical capital'; they are different categories

back: Technological progress allows more output from the same inputs, shifting LRAS and PPC outward
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students think technology only affects AD through investment, ignoring its LRAS impact

back: Occurs when government spending exceeds tax revenue in a given period
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing deficit (flow each year) with debt (accumulated past deficits)

back: Persistent deficits may raise interest rates and crowd out private investment, slowing capital accumulation and long-run growth
CLEP Trap: Trap: Ignoring long-run effects of deficits and treating them as only short-run AD boosts

front: Keynesian vs classical view of self-correction
back: Keynesians think wages and prices are sticky so self-correction is slow; classical view assumes flexible prices and quick return to full employment
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming the exam will always assume instant self-correction; many questions use the Keynesian short run

back: Real wage = nominal wage / price level; measures purchasing power of wages
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating nominal and real wages as the same when inflation is present

back: Nominal GDP growth includes changes in price and output; real GDP growth reflects only changes in output
CLEP Trap: Trap: Concluding that living standards rose just because nominal GDP increased

back: The actual impact of fiscal policy is the theoretical multiplier effect minus any reduction in investment from crowding out
CLEP Trap: Trap: Overstating fiscal policy's impact by applying full multiplier without considering interest rate effects

back: Positive AD shock: higher real GDP and price level; negative AD shock: lower real GDP and price level; negative SRAS shock: lower real GDP and higher price level
CLEP Trap: Trap: Misidentifying which curve shifts for demand vs supply shocks

front: Money neutrality in the long run
back: In the long run, changes in the money supply affect nominal variables (like price level) but not real variables (like real GDP)
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming monetary policy can permanently raise real GDP in the long run

back: Extremely high and accelerating inflation, usually caused by rapid growth in the money supply far beyond growth in output
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students sometimes attribute hyperinflation only to 'greedy firms' instead of monetary causes

back: Unexpected inflation redistributes income between borrowers and lenders and increases uncertainty
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing expected and unexpected inflation; expected inflation is already priced into contracts

back: Demand for a currency is from foreigners buying domestic goods and assets; supply of a currency is from residents buying foreign goods and assets
CLEP Trap: Trap: Reversing which side is demand and which is supply when reading FX graphs

front: Link between loanable funds and FX
back: Higher domestic real interest rates attract foreign capital, shifting demand for domestic currency right and causing appreciation
CLEP Trap: Trap: Ignoring the connection between interest rate changes at home and currency movements

back: Nominal wages that adjust slowly to changes in economic conditions, making SRAS upward sloping
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students think wages adjust instantly in the short run, eliminating short-run output gaps

back: The idea that when unemployment is above the natural rate, real GDP is below potential; larger unemployment gaps imply larger negative output gaps
CLEP Trap: Trap: Expecting precise numeric Okun's coefficient; CLEP usually tests only the qualitative relationship

back: Menu costs: costs of changing prices; shoe-leather costs: costs of more frequent transactions due to inflation
CLEP Trap: Trap: Mixing these up with opportunity costs of capital or tax distortions

front: International capital flows and interest parity
back: Capital tends to flow toward countries with higher real interest rates, affecting loanable funds, exchange rates, and AD
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming capital only flows based on GDP size or trade, ignoring interest rate differentials
